Award.AwardTitle: CRIF: Upgrade of a 400 MHz NMR Spectrometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities: Multi-User program (CRIF:MU), Professor Steven Suib and colleagues Christian Brueckner, Amy Howell, Nicholas Leadbeater and Mark Peczuh from the University of Connecticut will acquire a console and probe to upgrade a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer. This award will enhance research training and education at all levels, especially in areas of study such as (a) synthesis by molecular design of catalysts, surfaces, ceramics, adhesives and other materials, (b) synthesis and exploitation of strained heterocycles with alpha-unsaturation, including beta-lactones, (c) synthesis and study of pyrrole-modified porphyrins, (d) synthesis of molecules and the characterization of their biological properties in comparison to natural products, (e) development of new synthetic methodology for organic chemistry, particularly that using microwave heating, (f) investigation of covalent and non-covalent molecular interactions in polymeric materials that result in self-assembled structures in the nanometer to micrometer regime, (g) study cell signaling and cell migration by using small molecule effectors of cellular function, (h) synthesis of well-defined polymers, normally amphiphilic block copolymers, for applications in self-assembly, and (i) understanding the role metal ions play in intracellular and intercellular signaling using molecular photocages, and the photochemistry of nitrobenzyl and azobenzene chromophores.

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to follow the progress of chemical reactions, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solids and in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to carry out frontier chemistry related research and to train students in modern research techniques. The spectrometer will be used by undergraduate and graduate students in research projects and in laboratory courses.

Summary for the Public

 

CRIF:MU – Upgrade of a 400 MHz NMR Spectrometer:

Replacement of the Electronic Components

 

The development of novel materials, drugs, food additives, perfumes, detergents, paints, crop protection chemicals, etc. requires synthetic chemistry that precisely rearranges, adds, or subtracts atoms from molecules. For each reaction, chemists need to test whether the desired modification of the molecule has taken place but molecules are much too small to be seen with the unaided eye. Thus, spectroscopic techniques need to be used to elucidate structural details of the new molecules that have been made. Each technique provides clearly delineated information about one specific aspect of the molecule.

A Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectrometer is an instrument that allows chemists to determine the connectivity of a molecule, i.e., the order and geometric orientation of their constituent atoms. NMR does this by measuring the local variations of the nuclear spin of particular atoms, often hydrogen (1H) and a natural, but low abundance, carbon isotope (13C). Depending on what other atoms are present, such as (19F) fluorine or (29Si) silicon, other types of atoms can also be probed. This technique of measuring the local variations of the nuclear spins is also utilized in Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) used in medicine. In MRI the local variations of only one atom type, hydrogen, in one particular molecule, water, is probed.

In the NMR technique used by chemists, the nuclei of appropriate elements are probed and signal variations are interpreted based on the proposed structure of the molecule. For example, one hydrogen signal can reveal information about the local electronic environment and also provide some information about other hydrogens that are nearby. The combination of this information allows one to make conclusions about how atoms are connected in a particular molecule. In turn, this allows chemists to make deductions about how a molecule has changed in a chemical reaction.

An NMR spectrometer has two major components: a powerful magnet that ages slowly and a large electronics console that ages as quickly as any other computer. The console controls the acquisition of data; it sends a series of pulses that first perturb and then observe the spins of the molecules while they are inside the magnet. The current grant allowed the Department of Chemistry at the University of Connecticut to upgrade all of the electronic components of one of its 15-year-old NMR instruments. Thus refurbished, it allows graduate and undergraduate students in the department to acquire key data about the molecules they made. The upgrade saves time and resources and provides better information for monitoring their research progress.
